objtitle.title: *Christ Appearing to the Apostles After the Resurrection*

objinfo.printdate: c. 1804-05The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the second one printed c. 1804-05. The first impression in that printing session is *Christ Appearing to the Apostles After the Resurrection* in the National Gallery of Art, Washington (Butlin 326).
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.name: Yale Center for British Art
provenance.note: Acquired by Thomas Butts in 1805 from Blake; Thomas Butts, Jr., apparently by inheritance in 1845; John Clark Strange by 1863; perhaps the work offered by the dealer Francis Harvey in a catalogue of c. 1865 for £15.15s.; perhaps the work sold from the collection of the Rev. Samuel Prince, Sotheby's, 11 Dec. 1865, lot 275 (£4.10s. to the dealer Halstead); acquired, apparently from a dealer named Johnson, by Charles Eliot Norton in 1867; American Art Association auction, 2 May 1923, lot 13 ($6100 to the dealer Gabriel Wells); sold by Wells to Yale University Art Gallery in 1929; transferred to the Yale Center for British Art in 1979.

desc.objtitle: Christ Appearing to the Apostles After the Resurrection, Object 1 (Butlin 325)

objnote.p: "Christ Appearing to the Apostles After the Resurrection" illustrates Luke 24:36-40. Christ stands in the midst of his followers and shows them his stigmata, but they are "terrified and affrighted." Blake shows the apostles bowing down before Christ, with at least one clasping his hands together in prayer.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In this scene, based on Luke 24:36-40, the risen Christ appears to his worshiping disciples, who kneel on either side of him. Christ stands at the center of the composition with his arms outstretched and palms out, exposing the stigmata in his hands; the wound in his left side is also visible. He strides forward with his left foot, also showing a wound. His head is bent to the right and his downturned eyes look towards the disciples. Halo-like radiance surrounds his head and upper body. Three figures bow to the right of Christ. In the foreground, a gowned, bearded disciple prostrates himself with his face, lower left arm, and left palm pressed to the ground or floor. Behind him kneels and bows a figure with short, curly hair, arm bent upward, and palms probably together as if in prayer. The third figure from the front bends forward with his head down. His hair is curly and perhaps long. Four figures kneel to the left of Christ. The front-most figure, a partly nude male with short, curly hair, kneels and sits upright as he looks upward towards Christ. His arms are bent upward, and his hands are together as if in prayer. The next figure from the front bows deeply; his head and bent right arm appear below the hands of the front-most figure. This figure’s hair may be long. He bends forward, but lifts his eye and hands with palms together towards Christ in a gesture suggestive of prayer. The third disciple from the front, who has long (?) curly hair, appears above the second figure. We see only the back and head of the final bowing disciple on the left. The scene may take place in a room, with only a back wall and the floor pictured.

component.illusobjdesc: The risen Christ stands at the center of the composition surrounded by worshiping disciples. He strides forward with his prominent left foot; his right foot may be on tiptoe. The muscles of his left leg are clearly visible through his gown. Christ's arms are extended outward from his sides at 45 degrees, with palms out and fingers spread, revealing the stigmata on his palms. His gown is draped over his right shoulder, leaving the left side of his breast uncovered and exposing the wound on his left side. We can also see the wound in his left foot. With downturned eyes and head bent to his left, he looks down toward his disciples. His hair is long and curly, and he is bearded. A halo-like radiant glow surrounds his head and upper body. His mouth may be slightly open; he may be speaking.

Three disciples kneel to the right of Christ. The front-most disciple, who is gowned, bearded, and has long, curly hair, bends his body sharply forward in a semi-prone or hunched-over position to prostrate himself in a deep bow at the feet of Christ. His face is pressed to the ground or floor, as is his left palm; his left arm is bent upward at the elbow and rests on the ground or floor. His posture suggests prayer. His open left eye looks down at the ground or floor.

Three disciples kneel to the right of Christ. The second disciple from the front is young and wears a gown; he kneels and bends or hunches forward in a deep bow facing down and to the left. His left arm is bent sharply upward at the elbow. His left palm is probably pressed against the (unpictured?) right palm in front of or perhaps touching his face in a gesture suggestive of prayer. He is gowned and has short, curly hair. His eyes look down and his mouth is slightly open.

Three disciples kneel to the right of Christ. The third disciple from the front kneels and bends or hunches forward in a deep bow with his head down in a posture suggestive of prayer. Only his back, shoulders, and the top of his head, with its long (?), curly hair, are visible. He is gowned.

Four disciples kneel to the left of Christ. The front-most figure is a youthful male who sits upright with his legs bent beneath him in a kneeling posture. His arms are bent upward and his palms are together; this posture suggests prayer. With his head bent back and his right eye raised, he looks towards the risen Christ. His hair is short and curly, and a gown covers his lower body, leaving his shoulders and upper body bare. His mouth is slightly open.

Four disciples kneel to the left of Christ. Immediately beneath and to the right of the front-most figure, the head and arms of another disciple appear. Although the backs of the two middle figures on the left are not clearly differentiated, we may also see something of his gowned back. This figure looks towards Christ with upraised eye. His arms are bent upward at the elbow and raised in front of his face. His partially visible hands may be together in a posture suggestive of prayer.

Four disciples kneel to the left of Christ. The head of the third figure from the front is visible to the right of and above the hands of the front-most figure. Only his downward-bent head, which is covered with somewhat short, curly hair, is clearly visible, although we can probably also see his shoulders and his gowned back (not clearly differentiated from the back of the figure in front of him). He is most likely kneeling, like his companions, and hunched over, and may be praying like the other figures.

Four disciples kneel to the left of Christ. We see only the head (just right of the face of the front-most figure) and gowned back of the fourth figure from the front. Like his companions, he is probably kneeling and bent over in a deep bow to the right; he may be praying.
A halo-like radiance surrounds the head and upper body of Christ.
Christ and his disciples appear to be in a room and to be standing and kneeling on a floor. A wall appears behind them.

lg.l: WBButlin 325 reports possible traces of a date associated with Blake's monogram signature, but we have not been able to confirm this.
